TopicTitle: Good Guys Make The Worst Bad Guys

Articles.Content:
At least in fiction perhaps.

 

Here i s my scifi scenario. A race of humanoid aliens who behave instinctually in a responsible way.  Regarding all they do. You would think that would be great, and it is... so long they aren't up to no good.

See,  imagine a world where no one chooses to slack off on their job, instead accidents happen due to misinformation and sabotage. And individuals will flat out refuse a respobsibility if they do not want to be responsible for it, so to counter that. many jobs are contracted for a length of mandatory labor or suffer the consequences. Think of it as mandatory paid work, you do not get the option to not work.

Thus the only con among many positives of being responsible scifi aliens is that bad guys of this sort have an increased chance pf success... against more variable behaviored races like us. Against each other it's a toss up that will be decided heavily by other factors such as timing and opportunity/resources.

Anything you wish to add or discuss?

 

Edited March 2, 2020 by Spacescifi

That sort of stereotyping is lazy writing.

Vulkans are logical, Klingons are angry, Romulans are devious...
It’s so hard to track down evil when it comes from a former good guy who starts breaking bad....

It is specific. Star Trek aliens tend to act distinctly, so that viewers tend to see that they do not all act the same.

 

Babylon 5, while superior to all Star Trek in many ways, did not make alien behavior distinct, they simply all act like human cultures with no definite personality tweaking. Minbari= Religious human. Narn:  Oppressed people etc.

Interesting analysis, and somewhat true, given the fact that whatever responsibility an individual willingly accepts they are bound to carry through.

It's up to me in the end, but if I wanted to make them act less human they would put fullfullment of responsibility above all else. Even their lives and the lives of others, unless that was part of their responsibility.

 

To at least make their motives seem relatable to human readers, perhaps the feeling they get from fulfilling a responsibility triggers the pleasure center of their brain... much like the same effect humans get who are addicted from everything from sex to drugs.

 

Or take Wheatley feom Portal 2 as an example, even though the scenario is not identical, the feeling is.
